Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Parenting and Employment Outcomes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed dissertation investigates how information about partnership status (married or single) impacts workplace outcomes for mothers and fathers. Previous studies have found that due to lower perceived competence and commitment, mothers are less likely to be hired and promoted; they also reap lower starting salaries than working fathers and childless workers. Such negative outcomes for mothers are known as the motherhood penalty. In contrast, fathers experience a boost in starting salaries as well as positive competence and commitment evaluations, known as the fatherhood bonus. Findings of previous research, however, focus primarily on married mothers and fathers. The proposed research seeks to examine the mechanism of workplace bias by comparing cultural assumptions about single mothers' and fathers' expected workplace performance to that of married parents.

The proposed research is designed to test an argument that when the roles of caregiving and breadwinning are combined in one person - a single parent - employers' performance expectations for employee parents should be less affected by a parent's gender. Therefore, both the motherhood penalty and the fatherhood premium should diminish. The above predictions will be tested in a controlled laboratory experiment. In the experiment, paid undergraduate volunteers will rate a pair of ostensibly real (but actually fictitious) candidates for a job position. The two candidates will be equally qualified, of the same gender (male or female) and same parental status (has children or no information about children), varying only on partnership status (married or single). The experiment proposed here will recreate an evaluative setting where people make decisions about workplace outcomes in a highly controlled environment, allowing researchers to separate the effects of gender, parenthood, and partnership status on employment outcomes.

One of the main intellectual contributions of this research is examining the role partnership status plays in sustaining or changing gendered assumptions about parenthood and workplace performance. Understanding how bias is produced and sustained is the first and critical step in eliminating it and increasing tolerance and equality at the workplace. Social change in this area can be gradually achieved by institutional agents having access to research findings and educating employers about hidden biases in order to reduce or prevent them. Eliminating bias should serve employers by increasing the pool of highly qualified candidates. Most importantly, uncovering the dynamics of discrimination and seeking to reduce it should greatly benefit those with less socially valued characteristics - women, single parents, and caregivers in general.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project examined partnership status (married or single) effects on the motherhood penalty and fatherhood premium. Previous studies found that women are penalized for being mothers while men benefit from being fathers, patterns described as the motherhood penalty and the fatherhood premium. Consequences range from differences in the likelihood of being hired and promoted to significant disparities in proposed starting salaries (Correll, Benard, and Paik 2007). These differential outcomes have been explained by deep-rooted cultural assumptions about gendered division of labor in households. Mothers are expected to prioritize caregiving while fathers are prescribed to focus on breadwinning. Since caregiving is incompatible with the work devotion schema, which calls for unwavering work dedication, mothers are seen as less committed, less competent, and hence less likely to perform well at work. Conversely, because breadwinning aligns well with the ideal worker image, fathers reap rewards for being perceived as primary (if not sole) breadwinners. The project proposed that these effects – the motherhood penalty and the fatherhood premium – only hold for parents with partners. When the roles of caregiving and breadwinning are combined in one person – a single parent – employers' expectations should be disassociated from gender and the disordinal interaction should be significantly weakened.  

The above predictions were tested in an experiment, where paid undergraduate volunteers rated a pair of ostensibly real candidates for a job position.  The two candidates were equally qualified, of the same gender (male or female) and same parental status (parent or nonparent), and varied only on partnership status (married or single).

Preliminary results lend strong support for the motherhood penalty and fatherhood bonus for married mothers and fathers. In line with the main hypothesis, the motherhood penalty either declines or is eliminated for single mothers. Moreover, preliminary analyses suggest that in terms of the measures of hiribility and promotability single mothers fare better than both married mothers and single fathers. Results for single fathers suggest a significant reduction in the premium that their married counterparts enjoy, although these patterns are more nuanced.

The project contributes to the sociology’s areas of gender, stratification, and social psychology.  It extends experimental work on the motherhood penalty and fatherhood bonus by focusing on how partnership status influences cultural assumptions about mothers’ and fathers’ commitment, competence, and anticipated workplace performance. 

Ongoing analyses support the hypothesis proposed in the project that the motherhood penalty and the fatherhood premium only hold for parents with partners. When the roles of caregiving and breadwinning are combined in one person – a single parent – employers' expectations are disassociated from gender and the disordinal interaction is significantly weakened. These findings, once finalized, will change what we currently know about the motherhood penalty and fatherhood bonus by adding an important specification – they only hold for married mothers and fathers, respectively.

In terms of the broader impacts, by analyzing status-based discrimination and its specifications, the project brings attention to the sources of inequality.
